Literature Review: Somatic mutations in normal tissues have long been recognized as a key driver of carcinogenesis. Recent studies have shed new light on the mechanisms underlying the expansion of mutant clones in normal tissues, challenging the traditional view that cancer arises solely from the accumulation of mutations. This review aims to summarize the current understanding of somatic mutations in normal tissues, with a focus on the early stages of carcinogenesis. We will discuss the role of stem cell fate in mutant clonal expansion, the transient nature of this expansion, and the implications of these findings for cancer prevention strategies.
